verses.verse: (40:25) Canst thou drawe out Leuiathan with an hooke, or binde his tongue with a corde?
(40:26) Canst thou put a hooke in the nose of him, or bore his iawe through with a naule?
(40:27) Wyl he make many faire wordes with thee [thinkest thou] or flatter thee?
(40:28) Wyll he make a couenaunt with thee? or wilt thou take him for a seruaunt for euer?
(40:29) Wylt thou take thy pastime with him as with a birde, wilt thou binde him for thy maydens?
(40:30) That thy companions may make a refection of him: or shall he be parted among the marchauntes?
(40:31) Canst thou fil the basket with his skin? or the fishe panier with his head?
(40:32) Laye thyne hande vpon him, remember the battaile, and do no more so.
(40:33) Beholde his hope is in vaine: for shall not one perishe euen at the sight of him?
(41:1) No man is so fierce that dare stirre him vp: Who is able to stande before me?
(41:2) Or who hath geuen me any thyng aforehande, that I may rewarde him againe? All thinges vnder heauen are myne.
(41:3) I wyll not keepe secrete his great strength, his power, nor his comely proportion.
(41:4) Who can discouer the face of his garment? or who shall come to him with a double brydle?
(41:5) Who shall open the doores of his face? for he hath horrible teeth round about.
(41:6) His scales are as it were strong shieldes, so fastened together as if they were sealed:
(41:7) One is so ioyned to another, that no ayre can come in:
(41:8) Yea, one hangeth so vpon another, & sticketh so together, that they can not be sundred.
(41:9) His neesinges make a glistering like fyre, and his eyes lyke the morning shine.
(41:10) Out of his mouth go torches, and sparkes of fire leape out.
(41:11) And out of his nostrels there goeth a smoke, lyke as out of an hotte seething pot, or caldron.
(41:2) His breath maketh the coles burne, and the flambe goeth out of his mouth.
(41:13) In his necke ther remaineth strength, and nothing is to labourous for him.
(41:14) The members of his body are ioyned [so strait one to another,] and cleaue so fast together, that he cannot be moued.
(41:5) His heart is as hard as a stone, and as fast as the stythie that the smyth smiteth vpon.
(41:6) When he goeth the mightie are afraide, and feare troubleth them.
(41:17) If any man drawe out a sword at him, it shall not hurt him: there may neither speare, laueling, nor brestplate abide him.
(41:18) He setteth asmuch by iron as by a strawe, and asmuch by brasse as by a rotten sticke.
(41:19) He starteth not away from him that bendeth the bowe: & as for sling stones he careth asmuch for stouble as for the.
(41:20) He counteth the dartes no better then a strawe, he laugheth him to scorne that shaketh the speare.
(41:21) Sharpe stones are vnder him lyke potsheardes, and he lyeth vpon sharpe thinges as vpon the soft myre.
(41:22) He maketh the deepe to boyle lyke a pot, and stirreth the sea together lyke an oyntment.
(41:23) He maketh the path to be seene after him, and he maketh the deepe to seeme all hoarie.
(41:24) Upon earth there is no power lyke vnto his: for he is so made that he feareth not.
(41:25) He beholdeth all the hye thinges, he is a king ouer all the children of pride.
